Iâ€™m quite happy with how the site turned out. Since I have full access to the siteâ€™s code, I have full control over its styling and format, and I can do custom styling for specific pages. Pop over to the about page, for example.

Why leave Substack?

This blog has never been interested in building an audience. If I cared to get a bunch of eyeballs on my writing, I wouldnâ€™t write 5,000+ word posts or publish weird, sometimes experimental, obtuse poetry (that maybe isnâ€™t even very good). Regardless, Substack is ultimately a social platform. Appended to each of my posts were like and comment counters, and every time I opened its dashboard to post my writing, I was greeted with graphs showing all sorts of social metrics. While ultimately I donâ€™t care, seeing a graph of dwindling readership just doesnâ€™t feel good. This new site does not have any of this. It is simply a place for my words to live, as I had originally intended this blog to be when I started it over a year ago. It will almost certainly mean significantly less readership than I had already, but I wonâ€™t know for sure. Out of sight, out of mind.

However, the main reason I moved my writing off Substack shouldnâ€™t come as a surprise to anyone who is familiar with the happenings on that platform. Substack has a history of sympathizing with Nazis, and thatâ€™s putting it rather charitably. Just a few months ago, a notification was pushed to many of the Substack appâ€™s users, that directed them to a blog adorned with swastikas. A system error? Iâ€™m not eager to lend Substack the benefit of the doubt, given its past handling of similar situations.

Iâ€™m Autistic and transâ€”have you heard?â€”and live in a world that is currently frothing at the mouth to do a genocide on people like me. From RFK Jr. making up the dumbest bullshit youâ€™ve ever heard about Autism and vaccines, to the Presidentâ€™s nonstop attacks against trans rightsâ€”every time I open the news Iâ€™m greeted with a fresh wave of hate aimed directly at me. We are in a genuine crisis. The last thing I want is for my writingâ€”what represents my most personal inner thoughts and feelingsâ€”put up alongside hate-filled rhetoric advocating for the eradication of my people. Full stop.

I considered moving to another platform, but I didnâ€™t find anything that I was especially happy with. And whoâ€™s to say I wouldnâ€™t run into the same issue with another platform down the line? We see more and more bending over to fascism every single day. Instead, I decided to just make my own website where I have full control over my writing, where it appears, and how it is presented.

Eventually, catloaf & coffee will be deleted entirely from Substack. If you chose to join me on this new site, welcome! There are no comments here, but you can find my email on every page of this site in the footer, if you ever want to say hello.

entry.title: Salem // Pyromania
entry.content:
Salem

Photo by Jared Murray on Unsplash

That place, a vampire
Only the dead persist there
Linger too long and join their ranks

They prey on those filled of hope
With spirits unbroken
Till nothing is left but a lifeless husk

At night they prowl
Looking for the brightest of sparks
Innocence makes the nectar sweeter

Deep do their fangs penetrate
Crimson oozing down their chin
Just another victim of circumstance

Seen it happen too many times
Lost many a friend to that place
Promised myself I wouldnâ€™t meet the same fate

Felt myself withering
Knew I couldnâ€™t stay
So I turned my back on everything

Under false pretenses I fled
Claimed the spirit of adventure
To elude suspicion

Found sanctuary in the unlikeliest of places
Here, too, monsters roam the streets
Just as lethal, somehow more manageable

Script has been flipped
I am hunter, they are hunted
Still I am not at ease

The beating of wings echoes on the horizon
In the dark they creep closer
It wonâ€™t be much longer now

Years they scoured the earth
Looking for the one who escaped their grasp
Sin so unforgivable, it cannot go unpunished

Trained for this moment, yet
Fear clutches at my heart
Though I will run no longer

Come, ye beasts!
Come, ye vampires!
Come, ye creatures of the night!

Unfinished business we must attend
Ready thy fangs
Prepare to meet thy maker

Pyromania

Photo by FlyD on Unsplash

Itâ€™s funny
They told you the truth
Yet you kept on pretending like nothing happened

To be honest
I donâ€™t care about collateral anymore
Iâ€™m ready to raze it all to the ground
Just give me a reason

Iâ€™ll relish in the flames
Let the fires warm my heart
Watch the embers drift by
Twinkling like fireflies
Raise my arms high in victory
And declare, Liberation!

Iâ€™ve been dreaming of my demise since I turned nine
Never thought Iâ€™d make it this far

Crawled from the deepest of depths
Against all odds
Bloody and broken
And yet I remain

I wasnâ€™t given a choice
It was this or a noose
I chose life

My existence
An act of defiance
A warning to any who dare stand in my way
I will be denied no longer

Still you donâ€™t understand what this is
Still you fail to grasp the implications
Still you refuse to recognize your complicity
Still you shield your eyes from the pain you wrought

I am bitter
I am angry
I am hate

I have been denied life
I have been denied a childhood
I have been denied peace

You have denied me an identity
For the sake of your ancient ideologies
And absurd ideas about who I am or what I should be
As if you had any fucking right

You, who cannot see the forest for the trees
You, who is incapable of reckoning with their own behavior
You, who has utterly failed to uphold the values you claim so dear
You.

For this, you will be the recipient of my fury

Beware
This is my calling card
Deny me and be doomed1
Ere long you will lose that which you cannot replace

Soon weâ€™ll be bathed in illustrious flame
Flesh will give way to bone
Bone will turn to ash
And at last, I will be rid of you

  1. Hedwig and the Angry Inch, 2001Â ↩

link.title: Old friends and bittersweet goodbyes at the Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry

entry.content:
Photo by Jules Marvin Eguilos on Unsplash
âš ï¸ J.K. Rowling

Itâ€™s Sunday. Iâ€™m visiting some family in Tokyo. The air is sweltering but Iâ€™m taking refuge at a small, beat-up dining table in my auntâ€™s and uncleâ€™s house. Five of us are huddled around the table, eating French toast under a wall-mounted air conditioner unit. It softly hums away while the kids watch YouTube on an iPad and the adults deliberate what to do with our day.

We float through a few ideas, but nothing really sticks. How about that Godzilla exhibit, I say. Someone says they donâ€™t like Godzilla. We could do teamLab,1 my uncle offers. Ah, never mind, tickets are sold-out. My aunt suggests Takeshita-dori.2 No one seems interested. What about a movie, my uncle proposes. No one even dignifies that with a response.

My uncleâ€™s family is in Tokyo only temporarily. Iâ€™ve been visiting them each month, trying to make good use of the time that we have together. Itâ€™s been nice seeing my cousins. Weâ€™ve always been so far apart from each otherâ€”always on different hemispheresâ€”that weâ€™ve barely had any opportunities to interact.

Most of the contact Iâ€™ve had with them was when they were born. When I was in high school, I held the oldest in my arms right after he was born, and I saw the youngest for the first time over a video call when I was a freshman in university. She was so tiny then. Now, theyâ€™re both right in front of me watching a Minecraft â€œLetâ€™s Play,â€ faces sticky from maple syrup. Babies no more. I feel old.

I have lots of these kinds of moments nowadays: Something reminds me of something else that in my mind is just a year-or-two old and then I realize itâ€™s actually more like a full decade old except I can clearly remember when it was new and then I feel ancient and then I start to panic about my mortality and how Iâ€™ll be hitting 30 in just a couple of years and how I absolutely cannot be 30 and still a boy which shouldnâ€™t actually be a problem because Iâ€™m transitioning but like, what if my transition is a failure?

Iâ€™m spiraling. I tell myself to calm down; that itâ€™s a ridiculous thing to be having an existential crisis over some French toast at a comically small dining table at 10:30 in the morning. Deep breaths. Okay. Iâ€™m okay. I return to the present. Weâ€™ve still not settled on a plan for the day. I should probably think of some more ideas, else we might actually be here all day at this damn table. I love my uncleâ€™s family, but settling on plans doesnâ€™t seem to be their strong suit.

I know lots of places in Tokyo but I donâ€™t normally have to consider children. Hmm. What do kids like? (God, Iâ€™m so old.) Well, my students love Harry Potter, and thereâ€™s that studio tour somewhere in Tokyo that we could goâ€”the one with all the recreated sets from the movies that you can walk around on.

I ask if the kids like Harry Potter. They love Harry Potter, my uncle says. I tell him about the studio tour. He asks the kids if they want to go. The oldest says it sounds cool. The youngest asks what is Harry Potter?

Theyâ€™ll love it, my uncle says, letâ€™s do that.

We purchase tickets online, but our entry time is still a few hours awayâ€”a commonly used crowd-control tactic in Japan. We decide to bide our time by heading into Shinjuku for lunch and seeing the Godzilla statue there, because the kids havenâ€™t seen it before.

Wait, didnâ€™t someone say they donâ€™t like Godzilla? I guess they changed their mind? I canâ€™t keep up.

We take the train into Shinjuku. It is dirty and smells like shit, which is unusual for Tokyo but not for Shinjuku which is lined with bars as far as the eye can see. Itâ€™s not uncommon to stumble upon a puddle of vomit in the street here. Itâ€™s a lovely place.

While I guide everyone to the monsterâ€™s lair, the kids complain about the heat. It is hot. My clothes are starting to stick to my skin. Iâ€™m holding my pastel-pink umbrella aloft to provide some shade, but I can feel the band of my sports bra getting wetter by the second as beads of sweat run down my back. We havenâ€™t even been outside for ten minutes. I love this country, but damn, is the summer intolerable.

Soon, we reach the famed Toho movie theatre with the great kaiju peaking over its top. A massive claw rests atop the theatreâ€™s roof and a familiar round noggin floats above it. Its jaws are fixed open, frozen in a menacing grin. With its red eyes, it glares at the people meandering in the street below, going about their lives as if there isnâ€™t a giant 20-story tall monster about to annihilate them all.

Jie Yeu Teoh on Unsplash

I happen to visit this theatre semi-regularly, so Iâ€™ve seen this sight a few dozen times before but I must admit, it is pretty cool. The kids think so, too, but only for about twenty seconds, after which weâ€™re all standing on the street corner like, yep. Thatâ€™s Godzilla.

Itâ€™s noon, so we head underground in pursuit of someplace to eat lunch. We settle on a restaurant that serves various standard Japanese-fareâ€”okonomiyaki, yakisoba, and so onâ€”and wait in line. Japan loves to queue. When people think of the Japanese Experience, they think of geisha and kimono and temples and sakura. But in reality, it often looks like staring at the back of a strangerâ€™s head for hours on endâ€”not exactly the exotic paradise everyone hopes for.

Waiting in line means weâ€™re idle, and anyone whoâ€™s ever been around children knows that being idle is a very bad thing, indeed. Idle kids get bored, and bored kids arenâ€™t something that anyone really wants, so my aunt takes the youngest to go look at some other restaurants in an attempt to bide our time, but this is an obvious rookie mistake. Article 237-C of the Hammurabi Code clearly states that one should never deviate from a plan once it is agreed upon by all children present. (Probably.)

Anyway, itâ€™s too late. The restaurant weâ€™re queueing at is deemed no longer acceptable.

The new plan is a curry and onigiri joint around the corner. We surrender our place in line and march over to this new place, and a problem immediately presents itself: itâ€™s tiny. Thereâ€™s no way the five of us could fit in there. So what now? Do we go back to the restaurant we just left? No, thatâ€™s stupid. And weâ€™ve wasted so much time in our failed pursuit of food, that there isnâ€™t much time left before we need to head to the studio tour.

Letâ€™s just grab some onigiri and head over, my uncle says. We just ate breakfast, anyway.

Well, this girlie is going through puberty again, and she could eat a whole-ass bear or two despite the French toast from a couple of hours ago. But sheâ€™s also a lady, so sheâ€™ll keep quiet about this to preserve the integrity of our expedition.

I sigh, but not loud enough for anyone to hear. I must express my dissatisfaction, but not in a confrontational way because I know Iâ€™m being a little unreasonableâ€”just enough to make myself feel a little better about my lack of agency.

My uncle guides us through Shinjukuâ€™s underbelly for like, 20 minutes to find an onigiri stand, which is odd considering onigiri is a dime-a-dozen in this country and we passed approximately 83 onigiri stands on the way to this one. This particular stand has a specialty for spicy tuna onigiri, which the kids seem excited about, at least. I reluctantly choose an onigiri made of fried rice, making sure to take a half-second longer to order so as to express my displeasure at this whole turn of events. We wolf down our snacks, then head over to the tourâ€™s venue.

The site of â€œWarner Bros. Studio Tour Tokyoâ€â€”a name so obviously terrible it comes paired with a more descriptive subtitle, â€œThe Making of Harry Potter,â€ which makes for an absurdly long title in fullâ€”is rather unassuming. A well-manicured lawn dotted with minimalist sculptures resembling various iconography from the Harry Potter films stretches out in front of a rather boring, boxy building. The only dead giveaway that weâ€™re in the right place is the large Harry Potter logo above the entrance.

Yes, I kind of fucked up. Weâ€™re in Tokyo, one of the largest cities in the world, a place that really does have it allâ€”and I bring everyone to the Harry Potter studio tour, of all places. Weâ€™re here because of me. I did this. Why is a trans girl suggesting we go somewhere built in honor of an IP thatâ€™s the product of the reigning TERF bitch? Look, estrogen makes you pretty, not smart. I wanted to see the kids happy and I panicked, okay? We couldnâ€™t decide on anything, itâ€™s our last weekend together before everyone leaves, and I just wanted to have a good time. I know I fucked up. I know.

And Iâ€™m regretting it already. Seeing that massive logo looming above me makes me feel strange, a bit uncomfortable. As we wait in lineâ€”because this is Japan, remember, we love to queue hereâ€”I look around me and everyone seems pretty damn straight and very cisgender. Meanwhile, here I am in a full face of makeup, a pink T-shirt with a cute cartoon bear on it, and breezy bottoms that no cisgender man would ever wear.

The Harry Potter logo looks upon me with disgust. Tranny, it jeers.

Shut up, Harry Potter logo. Youâ€™re just a sign.

While our tickets are scanned one-by-one, I anxiously consider what the insides of this building might contain. I hope itâ€™ll be like the Harry Potter 20th Anniversary reunion, where everyone talked around J. K. Rowling, and anytime she did pop onscreen it was paired with a disclaimer that the segment was filmed years ago, as if the filmmakers were profusely apologizing for having to include her at all.

Yeah, I hope itâ€™s like that.

Itâ€™s not like that. As soon as we enter the building, weâ€™re greeted with a quote from one of the books, prominently displayed on a large banner and proudly attributed to the queen bitch herself. Oh god, what I have done.

We enter the main lobby: a cavernous carpeted space littered with benches and large LED displays running the length of its walls. To our left is a gift shop styled in the Ministry of Magicâ€™s iconic green-and-black tile, to our right is a food court themed like Hogwartsâ€™ Great Hall, and immediately ahead is a shadowy hole in the wall. Next to it sits a sign that reads, STUDIO TOUR ENTRANCE. We head straight there. I look longingly in the food courtâ€™s direction the whole way.

A map of Warner Bros. Studio Tour Tokyo. It fails to convey how truly massive a space it is. (Warner Bros. Entertainment Inc.)

Beyond the ominous entrance lie massive on-set photos from each Harry Potter film, presented with a 3D-layered effect. My youngest cousin asks why there are cameras visible in some of the pictures, as if the tour creators made a glaring oversight. Itâ€™s a studio tour, I explain, we get to see how the movies were made! Oh, she says.

Sheâ€™s adorable.

Weâ€™re corralled by staff into a dark rectangular room plastered with movie posters all along the front wall. My aunt points out one of the posters with Johnny Depp, and I say I donâ€™t remember him in any of the films. He was in one of the Fantastic Beasts movies, she says. Oh, I say, I never saw those. She puffs out her bottom lip. Thatâ€™s a shame, she says. Theyâ€™re fun!

On the back wall is a row of portraits of all the filmsâ€™ directors. At the end of the lineup is a familiar face: J. K. Rowling, with that stupid smirk that she always makes in photos. Canâ€™t she just smile like a normal person? It isnâ€™t that hard, girl.

I consider taking a picture of myself flipping off her portrait, but quickly abandon the idea as a large mass of people pushes into the space. The doors ahead are closed and weâ€™re all standing around looking at these movie posters weâ€™ve all seen a million times before. A staff member monologues about each of the posters. Itâ€™s very boring and very long. Iâ€™m not paying much attention because itâ€™s all being conducted in Japanese and I donâ€™t feel like applying my brain right now, and also I canâ€™t shake the feeling of the hole being bored into my head from J. K. Rowlingâ€™s smug mug behind me.

Finally, the doors ahead are opened. Can we actually start the tour now? Nope. Instead, weâ€™re being corralled into another dark and rectangular space. This room has a long LED screen spanning the width of the far wall, that shows Harryâ€™s Japanese voice actor explaining the tourâ€™s rules and teasing all the things weâ€™re about to see.

Like, yeah dude, just let us see for ourselves. You donâ€™t have to sell us on this. Weâ€™ve bought tickets already. Let us in!

The presentation ends with clips of fans dressed in wizard robes talking about what Harry Potter means to them. It feels like some weird corporate diversity video meant to show that Harry Potter is for everyone! I look around me. The room is very crowdedâ€”thereâ€™s probably a couple hundred people in hereâ€”but thereâ€™s not a single queer-presenting person in the room, save for me. I want to melt into a puddle and seep into the floor.

The doors ahead are opened and at last we can start- oh for fuckâ€™s sake, Warner Brothers! Another dark rectangular room? Iâ€™m beginning to think this tour is just one big practical joke.

This room is much larger. Itâ€™s a cinema, complete with a large projection screen and several rows of theatre seats. We seat ourselves in the front row and Daniel Radcliffe, Rupert Grint, and Emma Watson (queen) appear onscreen to give an introduction to the tour. If my math is correct, this is now the third introduction to the tour (that everyone has already paid real money to attend) that weâ€™re being subjected to. We â€œstartedâ€ the tour 30 minutes ago. The kids are growing a little impatient. I am too.

Thankfully, this introduction is shorter than the others. The theatre screen is raised into the ceiling, and behold! The entrance doors to Hogwarts. Itâ€™s pretty cool, I must admit. We all crowd around the doors, and a staff member asks the crowd if anyone is celebrating a birthday or an anniversary. No one responds. He asks again. No one responds. He asks again. No one responds. He nervously chuckles to himself.

Refusing to be deterred, he asks for like, the fifth time. A child raises his hand and pushes through the crowd. The kid is maybe 12 years old. The staff member asks, completely sincerely, if today is his birthday or anniversary. I burst out laughing. No one else in the crowd offers even a hint of a laugh.

Kill me, kill me, kill me.

The kid is instructed to push open the doors at the count of three, but he doesnâ€™t seem to understand much Japanese, and this staff member doesnâ€™t know how to handle this. (I mean, who could possibly have foreseen that the big Harry Potter attraction would bring in overseas guests?) Eventually, they figure it out and the tour is allowed to begin at last. We shuffle through the double doors and into a recreation of Hogwartsâ€™ Great Hall.

True to its name, it is pretty great. The floor is made of (fake) large stone slabs and the ceiling is simply bare lighting, just like the actual film set because the hallâ€™s ceiling was added in post. The walls are lined with the hallâ€™s iconic dining tables, and at each houseâ€™s section are mannequins donning their respective robes. At the far end of the hall, where the schoolâ€™s staff would sit, is the Goblet of Fire. Two mannequins resembling Fred and George Weasley with long white beards are sprawled out on the floor in front of the artifact, recreating the scene from the fourth film.

Warner Bros. Entertainment Inc.

A staff member approaches the goblet, introduces it, and then a burst of blue fire erupts from the gobletâ€™s mouth. A little slip of paper shoots out from inside it and the staff member catches it in midair, gasps, and shows the paper to the crowd. It reads HARRY POTTER. Everyone claps. Itâ€™s very sugoi.

The kids are loving it. Theyâ€™re excitedly bouncing around the hall, ooh-ing and ahh-ing at every little thing. Thereâ€™s nothing quite like being a kid.

Whatâ€™s that, the youngest asks. She points at some mannequins in green-and-black robes. Thatâ€™s the Slytherin house, my uncle replies. They look bad, she says. Yeah, I say, theyâ€™re pretty bad. She bounces away to look at something else.

Once weâ€™ve had our fill of the Great Hall, we move into the following rooms. Weâ€™re greeted with a behind-the-scenes look at the hallâ€™s construction and then a room highlighting the iconic moving marble staircase. Itâ€™s been rebuilt here and it actually moves!

Next, is a large space showcasing the sets of the living areas at Hogwarts. Thereâ€™s the Gryffindor and Slytherin common rooms, dorms, and Dumbledoreâ€™s office. Everything is just as I remember it from the films. Oh, thereâ€™s the fireplace where Harry spoke to Sirius in Prisoner of Azkaban! Thereâ€™s where Ron and Harry argued about girls in Goblet of Fire. Thatâ€™s the sword Harry uses in Chamber of Secrets.

Across from the Slytherin common room is an area where you can become spectators in a Quidditch match. The five of us are grouped up with about 15 others and are led onto a small set resembling the spectator stands from the films. Weâ€™re coached through various reactions while being filmed, then weâ€™re guided to a display that shows a Quidditch scene from Philosopherâ€™s Stone with our reactions cut in. Itâ€™s horribly cheesy, but the kids are going crazy for it.

I canâ€™t stop looking at myself, though. Jesus Christ, I look like that? The camera caught me from a 45-degree angle and my side profile is dreadful. Itâ€™s so angular. It screams â€œman.â€ Gross. I feel sick.

Trying to hide my disgust, I cower in the back while everyone else laughs at the ridiculous edit on the display. After what feels like an eternity, the video ends and I shove past everyone, then hide in the Room of Requirement. Bad move. Everything here is reflective, and now Iâ€™m staring at my distorted face in various pots and pans. Ugly, ugly, ugly, they chant.

It would be brilliant if I could stop thinking about being trans for just a single minute. Every waking second of my existence is consumed with obsessive thoughts about how I look, how I sound, how I stand, how I walk, how I act. I look at everyone around me and compare myself to them, which is a very stupid thing to do, but as I previously established, this girlie isnâ€™t the brightest.

And like, everyone in Tokyo is so hot. Both the women and the men. Everyone has these perfectly crafted outfits, glowing skin, and gorgeous hair. I want to be friends with all of them and learn their secrets. I want to date all of them and kiss them. I want to be them.

Then thereâ€™s me standing in front of an old chrome pot, staring at my warped face. I look like a blobfish.

An actual picture of what I look like. Werenâ€™t expecting a face reveal, I bet. (Kerryn Parkinson, NORFANZ Expedition)

The next part of the tour focuses on the learning environments at Hogwarts: Defense Against the Dark Arts and Potions classrooms, and the library. Wedged in between the classroom sets is the Mirror of Erised, in which Harry sees his parents in Philosopherâ€™s Stone. At the studio tour, itâ€™s been turned into a selfie opportunity. An orderly queue (I really wasnâ€™t lying about Japan loving to queue) rests off to the side, with a long line of visitors patiently waiting for their turn. My aunt and uncle want a photo with everyone, so we take a place at the end of the line.

I am not thrilled about this, but what am I going to do? Iâ€™ve been running into this issue for my entire life: Iâ€™ve always hated taking photos, for reasons that should be obvious, but if I object to taking a photo everyone acts as if I personally insulted their mothers. Iâ€™ve learned to shut up and just go along with it. Itâ€™s easier that way.

As we wait for our turn, I try my best to dissociate. It works. Now Iâ€™m numb and I donâ€™t really care about having to look at my reflection again. I watch my body from some high vantage point as we stand in front of the mirror. We smile, my uncle takes a couple of pictures, and then we give up our spot to the next group in line. My uncle shows us the photos. Everyone is smiling perfectly, looking so happy.

Isnâ€™t it strange that we always smile in photos, even if we arenâ€™t actually happy in the moment? We willingly choose to alter our memories of events, warping them with false records because god forbid we remember things as they actually happened. Our camera rolls depict much happier images of our lives than what actually occurred. Itâ€™s never made sense to me. The false smiles of mine that permeate the majority of the photos ever taken of me only remind me of just how unhappy or uncomfortable I actually was at the time. I can look at photos and recall the bullshit behind each smile: In this one, I said I didnâ€™t want to be in the picture, and then there was a big argument about it right before we took the picture. Oh, in this one, I look super happy but really I was thinking about going home and hanging myself. Good times!

We proceed into the Forbidden Forest. Thick, towering trees surround us. The ground is a soft, squishy rubber made to look like dirt. In here, there are no reflective surfaces and everything is cast into shadow, so Iâ€™m able to slowly regain my composure. I watch the kids run about the forest, giggling with excitement. Screens are hung on the walls in between the trees to create the illusion of dementors flying through the woods. You can stand in front of these screens and mime a patronus charm to ward off the creatures. Itâ€™s a big hit with the kids.

After braving an encounter with the forestâ€™s eight-legged inhabitants, weâ€™re spit outside in front of Hagridâ€™s hut and a cafÃ© behind it. A staff member informs us weâ€™re at the halfway-point of the tour. Damn. Weâ€™ve spent nearly three hours here already.

We decide to eat lunch. For real this time. The cafÃ© serves a host of themed foods, mostly consisting of British cuisine. I order the Slytherin plate: bangers and mash and an oolong tea. Itâ€™s fine. Definitely overpriced, but this is to be expected at a venue like this.

Â¥2,900 for mashed potatoes, peas, and a curly sausage? Itâ€™s a bit expensive by Tokyo standards. (Warner Bros. Entertainment Inc.)

Before we commence the second half of the tour, I stop by the restroom. I hang a right to the menâ€™s restroom because Iâ€™m not looking to start an incident, and lock myself in a stall. I hang my bag on the doorâ€™s hook and feel around inside for my mirror and lipstick, carefully reapply it, then brush my hair. This is a bit silly, really. Thereâ€™s a huge mirror right outside, but instead Iâ€™m choosing to hide in a smelly stall to do my touch-ups. Iâ€™m still going to be walking around in the menâ€™s restroom in a full face of makeup and feminine attire, but I guess itâ€™s a step too far to openly reapply my lipstick.

Anxiety is stupid.

We resume our tour and arrive at Platform 9 Â¾. The noble Hogwarts Express sits proudly at the station, steam billowing from its smokestack, impressing with its tremendous size. I stand in the middle of the platform, full of visitors going to-and-fro just like a real train platform, and it hits me:

Little Sage is loving this. Sheâ€™s fan-girling so hard right now. This whole tour is basically all she ever wanted. Harry Potter was everything to me. I adored the books, and when I saw the movies it was like a religious experience. To now be walking around in the very spaces I read about is a dream come true.

Because they werenâ€™t just books. They were a window to another world, another reality. A place where even the mundane was wondrous. A place where anything couldâ€”and didâ€”happen. The Wizarding World was everything the real world wasnâ€™t: Thrilling. Exciting. Happy. I wanted so badly to live there, and for most of my elementary school years I basically did.

I never had many friends. I still donâ€™t. As it turns out, being Autistic and actually a girl (even though no one sees it, really) doesnâ€™t make for a wealth of popularity. But at Hogwarts, I had Harry, Ron, and Hermione. I was right there with themâ€”running all over the school grounds, getting into wacky hijinks, fighting Death Eaters, and drinking Butterbeer. They werenâ€™t characters. They were my friends, and they accepted me even when no one else would.

But now, itâ€™s all wrong. Here I am on Platform 9 Â¾ and I should be over the moon, yet I feel so conflicted. Everywhere on this tour are various quotes from the books, all attributed to J. K. Rowling. Her dumb face pops up in various spots like a jump scare in some throwaway horror flick. Sheâ€™s inescapable. This world that had played such a pivotal role in my formative years now feels nauseating. Normally, Iâ€™m a big proponent of separating the art from the artist, but Harry Potter has been steeped in its creatorâ€™s hate-fueled campaign for far too long to ignore. Itâ€™s wrong. We shouldnâ€™t have come here. I shouldnâ€™t have come here.

But still the tour continues. Now weâ€™re walking on the green-and-black tiles of the Ministry of Magic. I stand in front of Dolores Umbridgeâ€™s pink dress, and it feels strangely fitting because by this point in the story the curtain has been lifted. After a brief stint as headmaster of Hogwarts, Umbridge is now in the belly of the authoritative Ministry of Magic and is no longer hiding her true nefarious nature; just as Rowling isnâ€™t hiding her hatred for people like me. I think of her stupid cigar photo. She may as well be the one in this dress.

Following the UKâ€™s Supreme Court ruling that the term â€œwomanâ€ does not apply to trans women, Rowling posted this image (edits mine) with the caption: â€œI love it when a plan comes together.â€ Cunt. (J.K. Rowling on X)

I donâ€™t know whether I want to scream, cry, or both, but I decide that the cold interior of the Ministry isnâ€™t the place for either of those things. We meander through a section showing how the booksâ€™ magical creatures were realized on screen, and then we hop in line for the Broomstick Experience. First, a staff member takes a group photo (ugh) and then whisks us away to a green stall with a broomstick suspended horizontally. My oldest cousin mounts it and is instructed to give various reactions and poses, while heâ€™s superimposed into a scene from Goblet of Fire where Harry flys away from a dragon, except instead of Harry itâ€™s now my cousin. Everyone laughs. The youngest especially.

Itâ€™s my uncleâ€™s turn. He makes crazy, exaggerated movements and the kids are bowled over with laughter. Heâ€™s a good dad. Iâ€™m laughing, too, but only because Iâ€™m trying to blend in. Really, Iâ€™m dreading being asked to get on the broomstick because I donâ€™t think I can handle seeing myself on camera again.

The staff member motions for me to enter the stall. I politely decline. Everyone seems a little bummed.

I am, too. I feel like a disappointment. I wish I wasnâ€™t like this.

Weâ€™re almost finished now. Just two main features to go. After the Broomstick Experience is an exhibit explaining foley-work, and then there it is: Diagon Alley.

Warner Bros. Entertainment Inc.

Of all the booksâ€™ many locales, this is certainly the most whimsical, which is probably why this set was saved for last. Its winding path stretches out in front of us, utilizing a bit of forced perspective that makes it all seem at least twice as big as it really is. Just like in the films, shops are jammed haphazardly together, painted in all sorts of vibrant colors, and constructed in impossible geometry. I waltz over to 93 Diagon Alley, where Weasley & Weasley is located. Inside are endless shelves of multicolored boxes paired with zany signs detailing their contents. In the middle of the shop floor is a statue of a child holding a large bowl containing purple-and-green candies. The statue has a concerningly round head and is hunched over the bowl, mouth unnaturally agape, as a steady flow of the candies expel from its orifice into the bowl. Beside the statue is a sign that reads PUKING PASTILLES. I feel a strange sense of kinship with the thing.

The set is immaculately kept and exhaustively detailed, but Iâ€™m quite tired of this place. Iâ€™m ready to leave, and not just because I feel weird about being trans at Hogwarts. Weâ€™ve been here for over five hours now. As impressively comprehensive a tour as this is, it is so very long.

Luckily, thereâ€™s only one stop left in our tour. We pass through a hallway featuring a spread of the Marauderâ€™s Map to the tourâ€™s final chamber. It is a vast, black chamber housing a staggeringly massive model of the Hogwarts grounds in full. Itâ€™s difficult to convey the size of it. The room is essentially two or three stories tall. We enter at the top and still the model towers before us. Itâ€™s a brilliant finale, even if it does feel hollow.

At long last, our tour has come to a close. Weâ€™re spit out into the gift shop, which is inexplicably larger than the Great Hall and Diagon Alley sets combined. I peruse the merchandise while the kids sort through plushies. There are wands, robes, hats, building sets, pins, stationary, confectionaries, Butterbeer, figuresâ€”far too much to list off, even if I could remember all of the shopâ€™s offerings. I cannot deny that this stuff is cool. Itâ€™s not junk. Itâ€™s quality stuff. I would totally buy an irresponsible amount of merch, if it werenâ€™t for J. K. Rowlingâ€™s stench plaguing everything in sight.

Itâ€™s past six now. We decide we may as well grab dinner before we leave, so we walk to the dining hall styled like Hogwartsâ€™ Great Hall. I order an English breakfast, which like the bangers and mash, is aggressively overpriced. The toast is branded with â€œ9 Â¾â€ in a meager attempt to tie the meal into the theming. It tastes like styrofoam. Itâ€™s a bit sad.

I finish my meal before everyone else because I ordered first. In Japan, meals are brought out whenever theyâ€™re ready so usually you eat when your food arrives, even if other members in your party are still waiting to receive their order. I watch the kids eat. Somehow, they appear to be getting just as much food in their mouths as on their faces.

Our kids have the worst table manners, my uncle says. I chuckle. Itâ€™s gross but also cute, in a little kid sort of way.

Eventually, watching the messy display in front of me grows old, so I look around the room. Weâ€™re sat close to where the dining hall meets the main lobby. I look toward the exit. Above it is a quote immortalized in golden letters that reads, WHETHER YOU COME BACK BY PAGE OR BY THE BIG SCREEN, HOGWARTS WILL ALWAYS BE THERE TO WELCOME YOU HOME. In small letters below, the quoteâ€™s author is revealed: J. K. Rowling.

Those words were originally spoken nearly 15 years ago, during the premiere of the Deathly Hallows: Part 2. It was a simpler time when the Wizarding World yet lacked the political undertones it carries today. Rowlingâ€™s hatred of the trans community wouldnâ€™t come to light until many years later. But in 2025, the quote suspended above takes on a more nuanced meaning: Hogwarts will always be there to welcome you, except for me because I am trans.

I get up from the table and capture the only photo I take of the entire tour. I lazily position the quote in frame and then my right hand with its middle finger extended. Like our group photo at the Mirror of Erised, it paints a false image of the current moment. It implies anger and defiance, but I feel neither of these things. Iâ€™m just sad, and tired. Tired of being sad.

I look back to my cousins in the dining hall, still painting their faces with their dinner. Theyâ€™re so innocent, so beautifully oblivious to the sinister bigotry lurking behind everything around us. They are free to run about and take everything at face-value. They donâ€™t have to hyper-analyze everything for its subtext, or consider whether they should even be here at all. Hogwarts is just a magical school from some old movies. Dobby is just a funny little guy. J. K. Rowling is just a face on a wall. I envy them.

For many trans peopleâ€”and Autistics, of which I am oneâ€”childhood is a blur. I donâ€™t remember my childhood much. I remember only a few things: a constant state of unease, the resulting persistent desire to no longer exist, weirdness from growing up in the church. Itâ€™s difficult to recall anything especially positive, but Harry Potter has always been one of the few exceptions. Now, I donâ€™t even have that.

We exit the tour building. The front lawn is now illuminated by moonlight. As we walk to the nearby train station, my aunt asks if Iâ€™ll finally watch the Fantastic Beasts movies.

No, I say, I donâ€™t think I will.

I Saw the TV Glow, A24
ğŸ‘€ Vague spoilers for I Saw the TV Glow.
â„¹ï¸ Originally posted on Letterboxd, with a bit of added polishing for catloaf & coffee.

Once one pushes past the initial fear, starting transition is exciting. Itâ€™s time to start hormones, buy new clothes, try a new hairstyle, learn makeup, and get a piercing or two. Eventually, though, some time passes and one has checked all those little boxes, and now thereâ€™s not much left to do but wait.

Five months into my transition, Iâ€™m feeling the lull set in. Of course, I can still work on my wardrobe and makeup skills and so on. But the initial rush of euphoria that comes along with all those â€œfirstsâ€ has come and gone. Now Iâ€™m left to slowly watch myself change in the mirror. Itâ€™s tough. I didnâ€™t realize how heavily Iâ€™d been relying on the highs of that initial transition period, so as I move into this next phase of my transition, Iâ€™ve found myself feeling especially dysphoric. Many a day has gone by where Iâ€™m at the verge of tears at every hour of the day.

Frustrated and wanting to do something to further my progress, I was playing around with FaceAppâ€™s feminization filter, hoping it would provide pointers on what I should focus on. (Yes, consulting an AI-powered filters app for tips on my transition is almost certainly a bad idea, but I was feeling desperate.) After feeding it a few pictures of myself from the past year, I came to a curious realization: in recent pictures, the filter barely touched my face at all and just gave me longer hair. But in pictures from the start of my transition, the filter changed my whole face. This made me feel a bit better about my progress. It helped me to see the genuinely substantial changes Iâ€™ve undergone in a mere five months. Of course, Iâ€™m still not anywhere near where I want to beâ€”hell, the app itself assumes my gender as maleâ€”but it was nice to be able to recognize the progress Iâ€™ve made.

Even so, the filterâ€™s recommendation was to grow my hair out longer. Fair enough. Iâ€™d already been considering doing so, however this meant more waiting around for things to happenâ€¦ not exactly the brilliant action-packed plan I was hoping for.

I was feeling lost. I felt myself beginning to slip as doubt crept in. Youâ€™ll never be a girl. Youâ€™ll always just be a dude in makeup.

I needed guidance, and there was only one place I could think of to go: I Saw the TV Glow.

I pushed play. Letâ€™s go to church.

Two minutes into the runtime, a gym class parachute lined with white, blue, pink, and purple stripes billows through the air as Anthems For A Seventeen Year-Old Girl by yeule hums in the background. I can feel it hitting already. My face is scrunched up, Iâ€™m sniffling, tears running down my cheek. Itâ€™s an ugly sight, Iâ€™m sure, but no one is around. Itâ€™s just me, my cat plushie, and TV Glow.

Soon, Caroline Polachek sings of girls with makeup in Starburned and Unkissed as Owen strolls through his high schoolâ€™s hallways. Iâ€™m losing it. In my first viewing, I cried here, tooâ€”albeit with far fewer tears, as I was emotionally stunted then. But tonight, with testosterone eradicated, my lips are wet and taste of salt. Tonight, I am one of the girls in makeup.

Ere long, itâ€™s time for Maddyâ€™s monologue, and I swear this is the greatest monologue ever committed to film and I will fight anyone who says otherwise. Maddy literally looks into the camera and says they pissed and shit their pants and it somehow works. I donâ€™t understand how it works, only that it does. Bravo, Jack Haven.

(For the steaming pile of dog shit that is Emilia PÃ©rez to have been nominated for Best Picture and not this is perhaps one of the greatest travesties of our times. Then again, maybe no one should care about an award show that only started requiring its judges to actually watch the films they vote on after 97 whole-ass years. I digress.)

(Actually, one more thing. Did you know Zoe SaldaÃ±aâ€™s Oscar statue is trans? It goes by they/them. Yes, the statue. Thank you, Zoe SaldaÃ±a, very cool. Next time you want to give a nod to the marginalized community that the film you won an award for centers around, try doing so in your acceptance speech. You know, the place where youâ€™ll have the most eyeballs? I. Digress.)

As Maddy delivers their speech in the planetarium, I feel something welling up inside of me. So many emotions. Fear? Hopelessness? Denial? No. Once, these were the things I felt in response to this film, but no longer. Tonight, I feel happy. Hopeful. Grateful for having seen this film and absorbed its teachings. Joyful for having finally discovered myself; for starting season six.

The tears are rushing down my face now. My nose is oozing down my upper lip, and I taste a rather off-putting concoction of salty tears and bitter mucus. My eyes feel swollen. Iâ€™m going through it, girl.

I start shaking. I canâ€™t control it. Iâ€™m squeezing this plushie within an inch of its nonexistent life and Iâ€™m wildly shaking. In this moment, I feel Maddyâ€™s every word. Every breath. Every step. This feeling is so intense I feel like I might burst. Itâ€™s overwhelming. I can barely handle it.

The monologue ends. My heart feels like itâ€™s about to burst out of my chest but I slowly calm down.

Now Owen is screaming in the Fun Centerâ€™s party room. Last year, this scene shook me to my core. Tonight, I watch in sadness for Owen, but feel at ease knowing that Iâ€™ve spared myself this fate.

Words cannot begin to express how much this film means to me. I know because Iâ€™ve been trying to put its impact on me into words ever since I first saw this film back in October. I wrote an 8,000 word personal essay using TV Glow as a framework for my own coming out story, and much to my chagrin it completely fails at communicating the transcendent power this film holds for me. The English language simply doesnâ€™t possess the verbiageâ€”and I, the writing prowessâ€”to convey these emotions.

Nonetheless, here I am trying to convey them yet again. Despite having seen TV Glow six times now and having poured over its script countless times when writing that aforementioned essay, this most recent viewing drew out an emotional response in me greater than ever before. Its magic isnâ€™t fading. Not even a little.

Iâ€™m justâ€¦ so fucking happy to be where I am now. Iâ€™m learning to love myself, and I owe it all to this filmâ€”to Jane Schoenbrun, to Jack Haven, to Justice Smith; everyone who made this work of art possible. This film birthed me a new life.

I Saw the TV Glow and trembled before God while she smiled back at me. Nothing was the same since.

June 16, 2025

âš ï¸ Does this need a content warning? I donâ€™t know. Listen honey, this piece is full of bitterness and resentment and hostility and a general disdain for any and all life. If youâ€™re not in a good place to receive that, skip this one! And if you are in a good place, hey, maybe skip this one anyway! Youâ€™ve got better things to do, I promise.

And like, obviously this post isnâ€™t safe for work, but if you clicked on a post titled â€œSad Bitch Hourâ€ thinking itâ€™d be safe for work, whoâ€™s the clown here? It ainâ€™t me, sister.

Sorry, whatâ€™s that?

Howâ€™s the transition going, you ask?

Oh girl, you want to know?

Are you sure?

You really want to know?

You really, really want to know?

Alright, Iâ€™ll tell you.

But just remember, you asked for thisâ€¦

Welcome to my waking nightmare.

Ugh. Fuck, why? Why??

To my great displeasure, I have awoken in yet another day. Today it is Sunday, which means itâ€™s the second part of this wondrous weekend Iâ€™m having. Yesterday was shit but maybe today will be better?

Of course it fucking wonâ€™t. Itâ€™s 2025, girl! Weâ€™re all rapidly plummeting toward the-world-as-we-know-itâ€™s death and the brakes failed ages ago. It only gets worse from here. Welcome to the new normal. Put on your big girl panties.

(Or donâ€™t actually, because you still have your male appendage so you sure as hell arenâ€™t gonna fit in them.)

I pull out my phone and start my morning scroll. Yeah, yeah, doomscrolling is bad for you, but donâ€™t worry I know what Iâ€™m doing because I heard about something called exposure therapy once.

Iâ€™m on reddit because I guess I hate myself, or maybe I have an unexplored masochism kink. Both are equally likely. My feed is comprised of cat photos, some whining about the absolute state of various video games, and a whole lot of trans-related posts. Posts like:

Someone called me Ms. at work and I really liked it, am I trans?

I want to cry every time I look in the mirror, whatâ€™s wrong with me?

Iâ€™m dating this girl who thought she was a lesbian until she met me and she says Iâ€™m not like other guys, what does this mean?

My boyfriend said Iâ€™ll never be a woman and called me a tranny, is he being transphobic?

God, this shit is like, so 2024. Bitch, youâ€™re trans. The answer is always that youâ€™re trans and you should break up with your boyfriend. Or something. Whatever. I donâ€™t care.

Today, I do not care. Today, I regret waking up.

I think Iâ€™m at a low point in my transition, honestly. Iâ€™ve ticked off a lot of the easy boxes like buying new clothes, learning makeup, and getting my ears pierced. Now Iâ€™m left with the hard, not-so-fun, long-term stuff like laser hair removal (maybe one day I wonâ€™t be a broke bitch and can afford it) and voice training and growing my hair out and just fucking waiting around for hormones to do their thing. I can actually see the girl in the mirror nowâ€”whoop-de-fucking-dooâ€”but itâ€™s basically just a waiting game until I actually reach her.

And goddamn, havenâ€™t I waited long enough? Get off your ass, girl! Why are you making me chase you? Meet me halfway, at least. Fuck.

I wallow in my misery underneath my weighted blanket for a while. I need to go into the city today to buy a business casual outfitâ€”or â€œcool bizâ€ as itâ€™s known in Japanâ€”for a conference on Tuesday. The only clothes I have that fit the bill are from pre-transition when I was bloated to all hell, and honey we canâ€™t be having any of that now, can we?

Thinking about going out into public like this makes me want to die, though. So I present an incredible offer to my rational brain (RB): what about todayâ€™s shopping, tomorrow? Thatâ€™s good. God, Iâ€™m so innovative. Steve Jobs should hire me.

Alright, itâ€™s a stupid fucking idea, but itâ€™s exactly the kind of stupid fucking idea that Iâ€™m currently prone to going along with, and sure enough RB falls for it. Ha, dumbass! Not even estrogen can vanquish the procrastinator within me.

I should probably actually do something with my day, though. I may be a sad bitch, but I at least have enough sense to realize that wallowing around in bed all day isnâ€™t actually as intelligent of a plan as I might think. Get up, RB commands. Ugh. Just a few more minutes. Get the fuck up, RB screams. Fine, Iâ€™ll get up but you didnâ€™t have to be a bitch about it. I was gonna get up anyway. Eventually.

I drag myself to the mirror and like, how the fuck do you think I feel about what I see? Dark bags under my eyes like Iâ€™m a drug addict, and two dayâ€™s worth of beard growth because I felt so gross yesterday that I couldnâ€™t be fucked to even bother shaving. I mean, whatâ€™s even the point if Iâ€™m just going to look like a dude anyway? At best, maybe I can look like a fag, but you know thatâ€™s not really the reason I started transition, is it? No one had any problem with pinning me as a fag before I started transitioning, anyhow.

Whatever. Today, I donâ€™t care about those things. Dysphoria? Ha, whoâ€™s she?

I step into the shower, which Iâ€™ve grown to have a very love/hate relationship with because I can look down at my feet and BEHOLD! Tits! â€¦ and a dick. Yes, this is what I am now. Somewhere between man and woman. A weird transsexual freak.

At least no one can tell if youâ€™re crying when youâ€™re in the shower. Haha!

Showerâ€™s over and Iâ€™m feeling like maybe I should try actually combating my dysphoria by trying to look good, instead of just throwing on a depression hoodie like yesterday. I switch on my razor and get to shaving. Little cuts start to appear across my face because thatâ€™s just what happens when you shave, I guess? I mean, itâ€™s 2025, youâ€™d think weâ€™d have a better way of shaving without destroying your face but I guess my face is just too sensitive, so fuck me. Better to look a little cut up than to have a beard? I guess?

????

While my face dries from that balm I slather all over my face in the hopes that itâ€™ll prevent my face from turning bright red and bumpy after shaving, but in reality my face still turns red and bumpy only a little bit less so than without it, I look through my wardrobe. Itâ€™s really stupid. 70% of my clothes are from pre-transition and I treat them like theyâ€™re coated in the bubonic plague. Thing is, plenty of clothes in that 70% are still perfectly fine to wear, but nope. Canâ€™t do it. Wonâ€™t do it. They have that filthy fucking boy stench all over them. Instead, I stick to my new clothes that donâ€™t fit me right. You know, the ones designed for hips I donâ€™t have? The ones that assume a bust I donâ€™t have? The ones tailored without a cock in mind? Yes, those.

Last week, a friend asked me why donâ€™t I ever wear a dress? Fair question. A dress wouldnâ€™t have the bulge issue. Still, itâ€™s not going to happen. You will never see me in a dress, I said, not for a very long time. Why not, they asked. I sighed and explained that if I put on a dress and look in the mirror and see a dude in a dress, I think I might just go postal.

If Iâ€™m going to try to combat my dysphoria today, I suppose I ought to choose something thatâ€™ll make me feel like not-a-dude. How about that skirt that I bought and vowed to never let a single other soul ever see me in because I have a crushingly pathetic sense of self-confidence? Well, I didnâ€™t shave my legs today, so thatâ€™s out. Whatever, itâ€™s Sunday and Iâ€™m not stepping foot outside. A cami and those pants I bought at H&M that I got really excited about because oh my god Iâ€™m wearing girl pants for the first time and then subsequently mortified once I put them on again at home and saw a clear outline of my schlongâ€”yeah, thoseâ€™ll do. Who cares.

I return to the mirror and push play on my â€œBad Girl Clubâ€ playlist which is supposed to be affirming and empowering, but today it just feels like itâ€™s mocking me for being bad at being a girl. Which, fair enough. I mean, I canâ€™t really argue with that.

Time for makeup. I decide to try a darker eye shadow today to reflect all these capital-F â€œFeelingsâ€ swirling around inside of me, like Iâ€™m Robert Pattinson in The Batman, which is a very funny analogy because he is a boy and I am not really. I carelessly smear it over my eyelids and add in some eyeliner with a pen. Iâ€™ve never been very good with the pen and today is no exception but fuck it, it doesnâ€™t matter because today I do not care.

Delilah Bonâ€™s aggressively feminist Dead Men Donâ€™t Rape blares out my speakers and girl, itâ€™s a vibe. I donâ€™t know if itâ€™s a good one, but itâ€™s definitely a vibe.

Finished, I look at myself in the mirror. My eye shadow is all over the place and itâ€™s way too dark for my protruding eyebrow bone that already casts my eyes into shadow. My eyeliner looks like a five-year-oldâ€™s crayon disasterpiece that they did on the wall while Mommy wasnâ€™t looking. I look like shit. Itâ€™s perfect.

Nowâ€™s the point in my morning routine where I take a selfie to document my transition. I tell myself this is a really good idea, but so far Iâ€™m not really convinced. It mostly just makes me feel worse about myself, if you can believe that, but yesterday I managed to take a photo so today certainly isnâ€™t going to be the day when I fuck up my 150+ day streak. I put on my best bitchy face and flip off the camera, as a notification from the Associated Press pops down: The U.S. attacked three Iranian nuclear sites, Trump says, joining Israeli air campaign as Tehran promises to retaliate.
